title: Aviation sub-committee 'rigged' to Heathrow result
text:
Aviation sub-committee 'rigged' to Heathrow result 23 July 2015 Save 
A new Cabinet sub-committee discussing airport expansion but featuring no opponents to a new Heathrow runway has led to accusations that the decision will be “rigged”. 
The 10-strong committee will be chaired by prime minister David Cameron and will review the advice from the Airports Commission, which recommends Heathrow expansion, over the future of aviation in the south east. 
However, the fact that no cabinet members opposed to Heathrow expansion, including home secretary Theresa May; foreign secretary Phillip Hammond; international development secretary Justine Greening; chief secretary to the Treasury Greg Hands and Northern Ireland secretary Theresa Villiers, has sparked a backlash. 
Richmond Park MP and London mayor hopeful Zac Goldsmith, who has long opposed extra capacity at the airport, said: “If the prime minister has no confidence in his home secretary and foreign secretary to make a decision in the national interest, then logically he should fire them both immediately. 
He said: “The fact that this same formula was not applied to HS2, which directly impacts numerous ministers’ constituencies, will lead many to conclude that the decision is being rigged in favour of the Heathrow lobbyists.” 
Cameron has promised a decision will be made on expansion by Christmas.
